>From: "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...>
>Reply-To: neat@yahoogroups.com
>To: neat@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: [neat] Re: Obsessive Optimization
>Date: Wed, 23 Jun 2004 18:23:16 -0000
>
>I haven't been able to follow this thread as I'd like to because of
>trying to finish my dissertation!  I wonder, are you guys going to
>write up a summary at some point of what was concluded, because I'd
>like to get a sense what the final word is without reading through
>the whole thread?  It seems like you've been making some progress
>towards figuring out what works and I hope to be on top of it
>eventually.
>
>ken
>
>--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "John Arrowwood" <jarrowwx@h...> wrote:
> > >From: Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@y...>
> >
> > >But this is getting into the realms of the obsessive :)
> >
> > I've got good reason to be obsessive.  Let me give you an example:
> >
> > Before I can evaluate my networks, I've got to calculate the
>expected
> > results.  I do that once and only once, and then refer back to
>those
> > calculations for each network.  That saves me from doing it 999
>times more
> > than I need to, which is good.
> >
> > My inputs are converted from pixel values to a 'relative
>intensity' in the
> > range of +/- 1.  So, naturally, I want the expected output to be
>in that
> > same range.  So, after I shrink the 144x144 to 9x9, I convert the
>9x9 into
> > the +/-1 range, and use those same parameters to shrink the
>original inputs.
> >   Then, I have to calculate the expected results, which requires
>taking the
> > average of every possible square area within the 144x144 region.
>There are
> > 1,005,720 such regions.  Calculating those expected results was
>taking
> > around 10 minutes...  I could have just settled for that.  But I
>didn't...
> >
> > I decided to keep things as integers until the last possible
>step.  Leave
> > the pixels as 16 bit unsigned integers.  To take the average, add
>them up
> > and store the result in a 32 bit long.  Convert to a double when
>dividing by
> > the number of pixels that make up the area.  Then convert that
>average to
> > the +/-1 range.  WOW!  It did the same amount of work in about 10
>seconds!
> > Talk about orders of magnitude!
> >
> > The next thing to attack is the time it takes to generate the
>evaluation
> > code.  Generating code that evaluates 500 networks on a single
>sample takes
> > on average of about one minute for my laptop.  It takes less than
>5 minutes
> > to compile and execute that code.  So a savings there is
>significant, and
> > there is definitely inefficiencies in the process.  So next on my
>agenda is
> > to speed up that process.  I'm contemplating writing code which
>outputs code
> > that is specific to a topology, and then calling that generated
>code with a
> > specific network in order to output the optimized activation
>function.
> > That'll be a debugging nightmare! But cool, in a morbid way...
> >
> > But I'm glad I'm obsessive, I have saved myself boatloads of time
>in this
> > experiment!
>
>
